Didn't check your profile, but mostly, don't ban the top meta picks. At least until Plat, meta isn't really important, so just ban something for YOUR lane that you don't want/know how to play against, or ban a Jungler you don't like.

Thing is, before you reach high MMR, the players' skill are much more important than the champions potential, because no one can actually use this potential fully. So you should be much more worried about a Yorick main who know their shit than by a first time GP who picked him only because he's meta. Except you can't know in advance you're against a Yorick main. So don't stress about bans, relax, and just ban something you *personally* don't like.

And if you don't really care, ask your team-mates what they want. Most people would want more than 1 ban ^^

Alternatively, you can use this website, when it works: http://bestbans.com/ (It currently doesn't, for quite some time already.)

Wait, let me repeat that back to you to see if I correctly understand what you are saying:

1. "The game has been getting changed to cater to casuals"

2. "It stands to reason that if the game is easier then it will be more popular among casual players."

3. "Casual players make up most of the player-base."

4. "**Therefore** Riot is flipping off all the veteran players to chase money from the majority."

I have a number of problems with this argument:

First, there is a big difference between catering to one group and flipping another group off. If you think that paying attention to another group instead of your group is the equivalent of being flipped off then that's actually kind of an entitled attitude to take. If a waiter brings water to one table but not another, they aren't literally flipping the second table off, they simply didn't provide the same level of service to the second group. Getting upset over it is textbook entitlement, and in a restaurant where you pay for service, it makes sense, but in a free to play game where nobody pays for service, it is not.

Second, statement #4 is a leap in logic. It is just as easy to infer other conclusions from your line of reasoning instead of #4. Such as, "Riot is catering to the majority of players in an effort to make the game more fun for more people." You're missing some supporting statements that would be necessary to draw a connection between "catering to casuals," and "flipping off veterans" or "chasing money."

Third (this is mostly just advice, not actually a counterargument), you made your assertions out of order which made it confusing to follow. If you want people to listen to you, understand you, and be persuaded to follow your point of view, you need to present things in an understandable order. If you present the ideas out of order you are more likely to lose your audience because they stop understanding what you mean. Statement #1 should have been after statement #3 and before statement #4.

> And let me remind you that their Devs suddenly can instantly add changes to pbe if the problem concerns their chosen one classes/champs if they are too weak. Suddenly every other big work is getting cancelled for a while just to fix their prescious ADCs for example, but they refuse to even start on thinking how to fix problems that are not that hard to fix but been here for months or years. It is obvious bias driven by greedyness.

[citation needed] Please give examples, rather than just vaguely reference actions in a way that could be construed any number of ways. As far as I know, they cannot just "instantly add changes to the PBE" because testing and development are processes with existing schedules and workloads. If you go to the grocery store and while you are in the checkout line you try to hand your cashier an item to scan while they are in the middle of picking up an item off the grocery belt to scan, you interrupt the whole process and make everything take longer. This is much more apparent in processes that are more complicated than scanning grocery items, such as factory work or video game development and testing.

Also please try to present your ideas without coloring the argument with made up examples of things that you imagine they think or say or do. Using such imaginings as if they are evidence of things only distorts the argument and makes it more difficult to sort through claims and reasoning.

I feel a lot of the same way.... in levels of play like mine, the typical pattern I observe in the mid lane is with assassins. I tend to hold my own in a rough stalemate with assassins, because I usually play a champion that doesn't counter them well because he's my main and I know him best. But, after about 15 minutes or so of me denying them kills, they just roam to another lane, and no matter how many times I ping, my allies usually ignore me and just die, allowing them to snowball.

If I ban Zed, they pick Katarina. If those are both gone, they pick Talon. If Talon isn't available, they pick Kassadin. If they don't pick Kassadin, they have Fizz. There are so many assassins, you could master 3 and never get banned out. There are so many champions that fill very similar roles that picking a couple of them makes you un-bannable.
Because most of the champions you want to ban aren't legitimately unbalanced, you just don't like playing against them.
